questions.prompt: What is the modulus of the complex number z = 3 + 4i?
Express z = 1 + i in polar form.
What is the conjugate of z = 2 - 3i?
questions.explanation: The conjugate of a + bi is a - bi, so conjugate of 2 - 3i is 2 + 3i

questions.prompt: The product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.
questions.explanation: z·z̄ = (a + bi)(a - bi) = a² + b², which is always real

questions.prompt: Using De Moivre's theorem, what is (1 + i)^4?
How many distinct 4th roots does the number 16 have in the complex plane?
questions.explanation: Every non-zero complex number has exactly n distinct nth roots. 16 has 4 distinct 4th roots: 2, -2, 2i, -2i

questions.prompt: The set {z : |z - 1| < 2} is an open set in the complex plane.
questions.explanation: This is an open disk centered at 1 with radius 2, which is an open set

questions.prompt: On the Riemann sphere, what point corresponds to ∞ in the complex plane?
questions.explanation: In stereographic projection, the north pole of the Riemann sphere corresponds to the point at infinity
By Euler's formula: e^(iπ) = cos(π) + i·sin(π) = -1 + 0i = -1

questions.prompt: Which set is the boundary of the open disk D = {z : |z| < 1}?
questions.explanation: The boundary consists of points that are limits of both interior and exterior points: the unit circle

questions.prompt: What is the principal argument of z = -√3 - i?
questions.explanation: z is in the third quadrant. |z| = 2, tan(θ) = 1/√3, reference angle π/6. Principal arg is -π + π/6 = -5π/6

questions.prompt: Every non-zero complex number has exactly n distinct nth roots.
questions.explanation: The nth roots are given by z_k = r^(1/n)e^(i(θ+2πk)/n) for k = 0, 1, ..., n-1, giving n distinct values
The inequality uses ≤, so boundary circles are included, making it a closed annulus

questions.prompt: What is (1 - i)^8 using De Moivre's theorem?
The closure of an open disk D = {z : |z - a| < r} is the closed disk {z : |z - a| ≤ r}.
questions.explanation: The closure adds all boundary points, giving the closed disk
